sect1.title: Choosing an XMPP server
sect1.para: It is recommended that you use the Prosody XMPP server. It is widely used and relatively easy to configure. Latest releases of Prosody are being made available as packages on the major Linux distributions.
You can also use ejabberd or another server if you prefer.

sect2.title: Package installation
sect2.para: Install the package using the appropriate tool, as demonstrated in and .

example.title: Installing Prosody on Debian/Ubuntu
example.programlisting: $ sudo apt-get install prosody $ sudo addgroup prosody ssl-cert

example.title: Install Prosody on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS
example.programlisting: $ sudo yum install prosody $ sudo addgroup prosody ssl-cert

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: Prosody can use the certificates created in . In the Prosody configuration, you can refer to the PEM files directly under /etc/ssl. Alternatively, you can copy the certificate files and private key PEM files to /etc/prosody/certs or create symbolic links from that location to the real PEM files. Whichever approach you choose, make sure that the private key file (or a copy of it) is readable by the user that Prosody runs as but be careful to ensure they are not world-readable.
Using the example provided, create configuration files for each domain you want to host under /etc/prosody/conf.d. demonstrates the minimum configuration for a domain.

example.title: Domain configuration file

sect2.para: Edit the file /etc/prosody/prosody.cfg.lua. This is where you can do things like enabling the LDAP authentication module or enabling SQL storage for user data.
Once configuration is complete, restart the daemon as demonstrated in .

example.title: Restarting the prosody daemon (systemd)
example.programlisting: $ sudo systemctl restart prosody Restarting prosody

sect2.title: User management
sect2.para: It is not necessary to add users manually. If users are authenticated by LDAP, for example, Prosody will dynamically create the XMPP account the first time the user logs in. If such a system is not in use, users can be added manually using the command line utility prosodyctl or using a web interface.
demonstrates how to add a user at the command line.

example.title: Using prosodyctl to add a user

sect2.para: To use LDAP authentication, make sure that mod_auth_ldap.lua is in the Prosody lib directory and add the LDAP settings to prosody.cfg.lua as demonstrated in .

example.title: prosody.cfg.lua settings for mod_auth_ldap
example.programlisting: authentication = "ldap" ldap_server = "ldap-server.example.org" ldap_rootdn = "" ldap_password = "" ldap_filter = "(mail=$user@$host)" ldap_scope = "subtree" ldap_tls = true; ldap_base = "dc=example,dc=org" ldap_mode = "bind"

sect2.title: Further reading
sect2.para: The Prosody web site gives more detailed documentation about setting up the user accounts and other steps.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: Modify the file /etc/ejabberd/ejabberd.cfg, add the server IP address and the path to the certificate as demonstrated in .
Set up the users: go to http://server1.example.org:5280, log in and set up the user accounts.
